lessons.name: Guitar Anatomy 101
lessons.info: Congratulations for taking the first steps to becoming a guitar god. First things first, you've got to learn the ins and outs of that sweet gitfiddle you're wanting to play. Check out this link and mark this lesson as complete whenever you're finished!

lessons.name: Your first chord
lessons.info: The time has come young padiwan. Time dip them toes in the water. If you have eyes you should be able to see a random chord image at the top of the page. In the image you will see 6 vertical lines that correspond with each string on your guitar. From the thickest string to the thinnest (reffered to as bottom to the top) E-A-D-G-B-E going left to right on the chord chart. The horizontal lines refers to the fret you will be pressing (first line from the top down being the first fret, second being the second fret, and so on). Try and get your fingar as close to the metal fret wire as possible. Make sure to press with a good amount of pressure as well, too light and the note will not ring out. The numbers in the circle refer to which finger you will be pressing with. 1 is your index finger, 2 is your middle finger, 3 is the ring finger, and 4 is your pinky finger. At the top under the chord name you will mey notice some O's or X's. When you see this on a chord chart it means you leave the string with the O open. Alternatively, if you see an x it means you do not play those strings, generally by muting the string, but we will get to that later. You strum all the strings in one motion. This will take some practice, but so does everything on guitar so buckle up. Your very first chord will be the G major chord. Check out the link then mark this lesson as complete once your finished!

lessons.name: TIMING IS EVERYTHING
lessons.info: Say it with me, TIMING IS EVERYTHING. In my opinion timing is the most essential part of playing music. Without it you will sound like actual poo. An invaluable tool to teach you timing will be a metronome. You can download free apps for this. Watch this lesson and play your G chord along with a metronome. Start at a slow tempo (around 60 beats per minute) in 4/4 timing and move up in tempo as you get better. Mark this as complete once you feel comfortable with the concept.
